document.docTitle: A new subspecies of Aporia procris Leech, 1890 hidden in Sichuan, China (Lepidoptera, Pieridae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new subspecies of Aporia procris Leech, 1890 hidden in Sichuan, China (Lepidoptera, Pieridae)

emphasis.docTitle:
A new subspecies of
Aporia procris Leech, 1890
hidden in Sichuan , China ( Lepidoptera , Pieridae )

paragraph.emphasis: The People’s Government of Dusong Township, Jinchuan County, Aba, Sichuan , P.R. China .

subSection.paragraph:
Further information on the distribution of
Aporia procris Leech, 1890
is provided. The population of
A. procris
from the upper Dadu River, W. Sichuan , previously recognized as
ssp. yaozhui Huang, 2021
, is treated as a new subspecies, viz., A. p. huangsiyaoi ssp. nov. , based upon evidence from external features, with its genital and molecular characters given.

Key words:
Pierinae
, Pierini , genitalia , phylogeny , dry-hot valley

As stated by
Della Bruna et al. (2004)
,
Aporia procris Leech, 1890
is a Palaearctic pierid butterfly with considerable variation in wing pattern, leading to ambiguity in defining its geographical populations ( Leech 1890 ). Based on previous literature,
Della Bruna et al. (2004)
compiled a taxonomic checklist including the subspecies of
A. procris
, an arrangement that has been continued not only in subsequent works by themselves (
Della Bruna et al. 2009
; 2013 ) but also accepted by other authors such as Wu (2010) .

Recently, Huang (2021) brought the aforementioned treatment on
A. procris
up to date based on examinations of a great number of specimens from diverse localities. Huang’s work involved correcting some erroneous classifications and describing two additional subspecies. One of the newly erected subspecies, yaozhui Huang, 2021 (TL: S. Qamdo, Xizang ), was previously illustrated both in Wu (2010) and
Della Bruna et al. (2004
; 2013 ) but regarded as another little-known subspecies,
ssp. nyanchuensis Yoshino, 1998
. In terms of distribution,
ssp. yaozhui
has a vast range, extending from its type locality, N.E. Xizang , to Jinchuan, W. Sichuan . Nevertheless, upon examining a series of
A. procris
collected from Jinchuan and Barkam, along with those listed in Huang (2021) , it became evident that the individuals from the upper Dadu River exhibit distinct external features that set them apart from
ssp. yaozhui
and other recognized subspecies.

Hence, the present study aims to distinguish
A. procris
found in the upper Dadu River, which is far from the type locality of
ssp. yaozhui
, and assign a new name to this focal population.

Eight males of
A. procris
collected from the upper Dadu River were examined: 1 ♂ , Suomo, Barkam, Aba, Sichuan , China , 8.VII.2023 , H.X. Zhang leg. (collection of H.Z. Li, CHZL hereafter, voucher BK1). 7 ♂♂ , Jinchuan, Aba, Sichuan , China ,
27. V .2023
, H.Z. Li leg., three of which were sequenced for molecular analysis ( CHZL ; JC1–JC3; access numbers OR146971–OR146973). The following
A. p. procris
from adjacent areas were also examined for comparison: several specimens from areas between Jiangda (Gyamda) and Jinchuan (unpublished data, C.J. Chang pers. comm.); 1 ♂ , Mt. Siguniang, Xiaojin, Aba, Sichuan , 7.VII.2020 , H.Z. Li leg. ( CHZL ; SGN1; OR146970); 3 ♂♂ , Yala Snow Mountain, Ganzi, Sichuan , 1500m , 15–20.VIII.2022 , Ding-Le-Heng Lv leg. ( CHZL ; YL1–YL3; OR146967–OR1469679).

Meanwhile, all currently known subspecies of
A. procris
were analyzed by examining the illustrations in the previous works, including (i)
ssp. procris
figured in Chou (1994) ,
Della Bruna et al. (2003)
, Wu (2010) , Mao (2015) , Tian (2017) and Huang (2021) ; (ii)
ssp. sinensis ( Bang-Haas, 1927 )
figured in
Della Bruna et al. (2009)
and Huang (2021) ; (iii)
ssp. nyanchuensis Yoshino, 1998
figured in Yoshino (1998) , Kocman (1999) and Huang (2021) ; (iv)
ssp. lancangica Della Bruna, Gallo & Sbordoni, 2003
figured in Koiwaya (1989) , Yoshino (2001) ,
Della Bruna et al. (2003)
, Tian (2017) and Huang (2021) ; (v)
ssp. wangjiaqii Huang, 2021
figured in Huang (2021) and
Pan et al. (2021)
and (vi)
ssp. yaozhui
figured in
Della Bruna et al. (2004)
, Wu (2010) and Huang (2021) .

Terminology for genitalia follows Klots (1970) and
Della Bruna et al. (2013)
. The holotype will be deposited at the Chongqing Museum of Natural History, Beibei, Chongqing ( CMNH ).

The Cytb gene is chosen for genetic distances and phylogenetic analyses. DNA extractions were conducted by Beijing Tsingke Biotech Co., Ltd. ( Beijing , China ). The PCR reaction was applied in a 30 µL system by using 15 µL of Mix (I-5TM 2×High Fidelity Master Mix, Beijing Tsingke Biotech Co., Ltd.), 1 µL of gDNA, 12 µL of dH 2 O, and 1 µL of each of forward and reverse primers (the general primers CB1 and CB2 utilized). The thermal profile of PCR consisted of a pre-denaturation at 98°C for 3 min, 37 cycles of denaturation at 98°C for 10 s, annealing at 53°C for 15 s, and elongation at 72°C for 15 s, then a final elongation at 72°C for 5 min.

paragraph.tableNote: * indicates a misidentification (see the text remarks for more information).

subSection.paragraph:
The
A. procris
inhabiting the upper Dadu River displays distinct morphological characters that would allow its differentiation from all other named subspecies. In particular, it can be distinguished from the nominotypical subspecies by the less pronounced streaks and less dusted veins on the hindwing underside ( Figs. 1–2 ). Meanwhile, this newly found population can be easily separated from
ssp. yaozhui
by the uniformly distributed coloration on the hindwing underside, whereas this becomes paler in the central areas of spaces in the latter subspecies (
Della Bruna et al. 2013
; Hang 2021) ( Figs. 1–2 ). Additionally, the localities inhabited by the Jinchuan and Barkam populations appear to be situated within the extensive range of the nominate subspecies, thereby impeding the establishment of Tibetan
ssp. yaozhui
in Sichuan ( Fig. 5 ). Therefore, considering these superficial distinctions and zoogeographical perspectives, the Jinchuan and Barkam representatives, once recognized as
ssp. yaozhui
, deserve to be assigned to a new taxon.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Habitus of
Aporia procris
from Sichuan, China. A:
ssp. huangsiyaoi
nov. from the upper Dadu River; BK1, ♂, Barkam, Aba; JC1 – 3, ♂♂, Jinchuan, Aba. B:
ssp. procris
from adjacent areas; SGN1, ♂, Mt. Siguniang, Aba; YL1–3, ♂♂, Mt. Yala, Ganzi.

FIGURE 2. Diagnoses of
Aporia procris huangsiyaoi
ssp. nov.
and two related subspecies.

FIGURE 3. Photographs of
Aporia procris huangsiyaoi
ssp. nov.
in nature, puddling with other congeners.

FIGURE 4. Male genitalia of
Aporia procris huangsiyaoi
ssp. nov.
la = lateral view, ds = dorsal view, po = posterior view.

subSection.paragraph:
However, given the embedded distribution pattern of
A. procris
from Jinchuan and Barkam, in conjunction with the notable subspecific diversity of this species in the Sino-Himalayan regions, it is possible that there could be multiple species within
A. procris
rather than a single species. However, there is no reliable geographical variation in male genitalia among specimens of all subspecies ( Koiwaya 1989 ; S. J. Hu et al. 2021; Huang 2021 ) ( Fig. 4 ), suggesting they are conspecific, a view also shared by Huang (2021) . Moreover, the low molecular divergence between the population from Jinchuan and the nominotypical subspecies also confirms their conspecificity, with only a singleton difference in Cytb (av. 0.25% in K2P) ( Fig. 6 ).

In conclusion, treating this potential taxon as a subspecies is preferable to a distinct species, supported by the homology of genital structures and by the evidence from molecular phylogeny. Hence, a new subspecies-level taxon is proposed and described below.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. Distribution map of
Aporia procris
. The type localities are represented by the letter T. The dry-hot valley in the upper Dadu River is highlighted in red. Source from references in Material and methods.

heading.emphasis:
Aporia procris huangsiyaoi
ssp. nov. (Chinese name: DZỪẰNJOiŵ川亚ª)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Aporia procris yaozhui Huang, 2021: 342
for two ♂ from N. Jinchuan, PTs of yaozhui + 369, fig. 65 for ♂ + 367, figs. ap14 for ♂ genitalia.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype :
♂ , Bayigou , Zhenglitang , Dusong , Jinchuan , Aba , Sichuan , China , ca.
2400 m
,
27.V.2023
, H.Z. Li leg. (will be deposited to CMNH )
.
Paratypes :
6 ♂♂ , collection data same as the holotype ( CHZL )
;
1 ♂ , Suomo , Barkam , Aba , Sichuan , China ,
8.VII.2023
, H.X. Zhang leg. ( CHZL )
.

Description. Male . ( Fig. 1 ) Antenna black with white tip. Upperside ground color white, sometimes tinged with pale yellow. Venation upperside black, tending to broaden at end in forewing but poorly developed in basal areas of hindwing. Forewing upperside discocellular bar wide with a series of postdiscal black streaks present in spaces 2–7 but out of line at vein 4. Forewing underside generally similar to upperside but with all black markings less prominent and apex yellower. Hindwing upperside with fuzzy sagittate streaks in postdiscal areas, while streaks and black veins conspicuous on underside with ground color yellower. Genitalia. ( Fig. 4 ) Vinculum slender. Saccus about half length of vinculum, short and robust. Tegumen and uncus broad at base with terminal part somewhat gradually narrowed into a point. Valva more or less triangular with a fovea in the middle basal region. Juxta and transtilla lamellar, posteriorly V-shaped and Y-shaped respectively. Phallus curved with a protruded trochanter.

Diagnosis. This new subspecies can be distinguished from all six subspecies of
A. procris
by the combination of the following characteristics ( Fig. 2 ):

1. Sagittate markings on the hindwing underside are less developed, but not obscure as in
ssp. nyanchuensis
, whereas the markings are more elongated and closer to the termen in other subspecies.

2. Veins on the hindwing underside are less dusted, while the veins are heavily covered with black scales in other subspecies except
ssp. yaozhui
.

3. Background on the hindwing underside is unicolorous, similar to that of
ssp. procris
and
ssp. sinensis
, whereas the coloration is more or less not uniformly distributed in other subspecies.
Variation. Ground color on the hindwing underside varies from sulfur yellow to pale yellow ( Fig. 1 ).
Distribution. Currently only known from Jinchuan and Barkam (W. Sichuan , China ).
Etymology. The subspecific name is dedicated to Mr. Si-Yao Huang, who frequently offers the author taxonomic help.

Ecology. In Jinchuan, this butterfly can be encountered in puddling posture around sandy moist spots on the banks of forest streams at ca. 2400m , mixed with
A. goutellei (Oberthür, 1886)
,
A. bernardi Koiwaya, 1989
,
Pieris venata Leech, 1891
,
P. davidis Oberthür, 1876
, and
P. stotzneri (Draeseke, 1924)
. It is noteworthy that this butterfly disappears at higher elevations (alt.> 2900m ) where
P. dubernardi Oberthür, 1884
is found, sympatric with other pierid species mentioned above.

Remarks. Both the photos provided by Ding (2017) and its locality from Shaanxi verify that the gene sequences of an “
A. procris
” enumerated in Ding & Zhang (2017) , which bears a significant genetic distance from other
A. procris
, av. 7.18%, is definitely a misidentification of
A. tsinglingica (Verity, [1911])
( Fig. 6 ). This issue probably comes from the first version of a well-known monograph edited by Chou (1994) , where a pair of
A. tsinglingica
was misidentified as
A. procris
. Although Chou noted his misidentification and corrected it in his later works ( Chou 1998 ; 2000 ), some authors, such as Shang & Tian (2017) , still followed the misleading opinion in Chou’s early work.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6. Phylogenetic tree of the genus
Aporia
inferred from ML analysis of Cytb with bootstrap support values (SH-aLRT support/ultrafast bootstrap support). A misidentification is marked with an asterisk (see text remarks for more information).

subSection.paragraph:
The specimens depicted in the literature and the additional distribution information give rise to the current view that
ssp. draesekei Bang-Haas, 1927
(TL: Songpan, N. Sichuan ), a previously supposed subspecies of
A. procris
from N. Sichuan , is not supported by reliable diagnostic characteristics and already synonymized with the nominate subspecies ( Huang 2021 ). Accordingly, all populations from Sichuan are currently considered nominotypical, with the exception of the phenotypically divergent population from the upper Dadu River ( Fig. 5 ). Although the topology of this new subspecies, inferred from the Cytb gene, is not monophyletic, this phenomenon is not uncommon because infraspecific differences in pierids do not always manifest in mitochondrial genes (S.J. Hu et al. 2021;
Zhang et al. 2022
; Huang 2023 ) ( Fig. 6 ).

The author would like to express his sincere gratitude to Mr. Si-Yao Huang (Bonn) for his guide on molecular works and for providing important literature. In addition, thanks are due to Messrs. Hao Huang (Qingdao) and Yong-Xiang Hou (Guangzhou) for some suggestions, to Mr. Chen-Jui Chang (Taichung) for sharing valuable distribution information, to Messrs. Chuan Chen (Mianyang), Shuai Tan (Jingdezhen), Li-Hua Xu (Fuxin), and Hao-Xing Zhang (Chengdu) for loaning material from diverse localities, and to Dr. Hao Xu (Mianyang) and Mr. Yang Duan (Xianyang) for guiding geographical knowledge. Besides, special thanks to the reviewers and editor for their valuable comments on the manuscript, and to Mr. Adam Cotton (Chiang Mai) for improving the English. Last but not least, thanks must go to the People’s Government of Dusong Township, Jinchuan County, where the author works, for support of his taxonomic research.
